topic.name: Macroeconomics: National & Global Systems
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Macroeconomics: National & Global Systems in History & Social Studies

objectives.objective_text: Identify good times and hard times.
Name the Great Depression.
Identify signs of a growing economy.
Identify sharing rules vs. trading rules.
Name the government as a rule-maker.
Identify a 'Mixed Economy' (most countries).
Identify taxes as money we give the government.
Name roads and schools as things taxes pay for.
Identify the National Debt.
Identify that candy costs more now than before.
Name money losing its value.
Identify Hyperinflation.
Identify a rich country vs. a poor country.
Name jobs as how people earn money.
Identify the 'Standard of Living'.
Identify the bank where money is kept.
Name the 'Fed' as the bank for banks.
Identify the Central Bank.
Recall that sometimes people lose jobs.
Observe that businesses open and close.
Recall that in some places, the king owns everything.
Observe that in America, people own businesses.
Recall that the government spends money.
Observe that we pay tax at the store.
Recall a story about wheelbarrows of money (Germany).
Observe prices going up.
Recall that it is good when people have work.
Observe that prices change over time.
Recall that interest is money paid for borrowing.
Observe coins and bills.
Summarize the Boom and Bust cycle.
Explain a Recession (economy shrinks).
Explain 'Creative Destruction'.
Defend the resilience of the market economy.
Summarize the Free Market (people decide).
Explain the Command Economy (government decides).
Explain the role of incentives in different systems.
Defend the moral superiority of voluntary exchange.
Summarize where tax money goes (Military, Roads, Schools).
Explain the difference between a Deficit (yearly) and Debt (total).
Explain the Laffer Curve (tax rates vs. revenue).
Defend a biblical view of taxation and limited government.
Summarize Inflation (money buys less).
Explain why printing too much money is bad.
Explain the 'Wage-Price Spiral'.
Defend sound money principles.
Summarize what GDP is (all the money a country makes).
Explain what 'Unemployment' means.
Explain the limitations of GDP (doesn't measure happiness or volunteer work).
Defend the use of Real GDP vs. Nominal GDP.
Summarize what the Federal Reserve does.
Explain Interest Rates (the price of money).
Explain Fractional Reserve Banking.
Defend or critique the fiat money system.
Compare a Depression with a Recession.
Analyze the phases: Expansion, Peak, Contraction, Trough.
Interpret the psychological factor in economic cycles.
Connect historical events to economic downturns.
Compare Capitalism with Socialism/Communism.
Analyze Adam Smith's 'Invisible Hand'.
Interpret the tragedy of central planning (shortages).
Connect private property rights to prosperity.
Compare high taxes with low taxes.
Analyze the federal budget process.
Interpret Progressive vs. Regressive taxes.
Connect government spending to economic stimulus.
Compare the price of a car in 1950 vs. today.
Analyze the causes of inflation (Demand-Pull vs. Cost-Push).
Interpret the impact of inflation on savings.
Connect deflation to the Great Depression.
Compare a recession (bad times) with growth (good times).
Analyze the components of GDP (Consumption, Investment, Government, Net Exports).
Interpret the Business Cycle (Boom and Bust).
Connect the CPI (Consumer Price Index) to the cost of living.
Compare easy money (low rates) with tight money (high rates).
Analyze how the Fed controls the money supply.
Interpret the effect of raising interest rates on inflation.
Connect the banking system to the economy.
Evaluate the government's role in smoothing the cycle.
Evaluate the efficiency of markets vs. state control.
Evaluate the long-term impact of national debt.
Evaluate the winners and losers of inflation (Debtors vs. Savers).
Evaluate the trade-off between unemployment and inflation (Phillips Curve).
Evaluate the independence of the Federal Reserve.
Construct an analysis of the causes of the Business Cycle.
Synthesize Austrian vs. Keynesian business cycle theories.
Construct a critique of Marxist economic theory.
Synthesize the history of the Cold War as an economic conflict.
Construct an argument for or against Keynesian stimulus.
Synthesize the political challenges of balancing the budget.
Construct an explanation of the Quantity Theory of Money.
Synthesize the history of fiat currency vs. the gold standard.
Construct an analysis of current economic indicators.
Synthesize the impact of productivity on national wealth.
Construct a flowchart of how money is created.
Synthesize the role of monetary policy in the 2008 financial crisis.
